docs.lead_paragraph: Arthur Andersen, one of the most venerable names in corporate America, has now become the first major accounting firm ever indicted, as a result of its role in the demise of Enron. Although the case involves only a single count of obstruction of justice, the steady flow of clients bolting to find a new auditor is likely to become a tidal wave. The Justice Department's move, extraordinarily swift and severe, befits the significance of the case and the urgent need to shore up public confidence in the integrity of financial markets. This and any subsequent criminal charges filed against Enron principals, however, should not detract Congress from the need to press ahead with major reforms of accounting and corporate practices.
docs.abstract: Editorial on Justice Department's extraordinarily swift, severe action against Arthur Andersen, first major accounting firm ever indicted, as result of its role in demise of Enron Corp; suggests Congress study Paul Volcker's proposal for saving company as blueprintfor reforming industry

docs.snippet: It didn't seem like the scandal surrounding the collapse of the Enron Corporation could get any worse. Then it did. In a flood of revelations, documents were released from a Congressional committee showing that the company's chairman had received ...
docs.lead_paragraph: It didn't seem like the scandal surrounding the collapse of the Enron Corporation could get any worse. Then it did. In a flood of revelations, documents were released from a Congressional committee showing that the company's chairman had received an anonymous letter from an employee in August, giving him a heads-up on the problems at Enron months before the company unraveled. The chairman, Kenneth L. Lay, ordered a legal review, while still chatting up the prospects for the company's stock. Then, the company's auditors, Arthur Andersen & Company, fired the partner who handled the Enron account, saying that he had led an effort to destroy documents in the days after the Securities and Exchange Commission requested documents from the company. And there doesn't seem to be an end in sight. Kurt Eichenwald

docs.lead_paragraph: The board that oversees Florida's $94 billion state pension fund authorized fund directors to sue Alliance Capital Management L.P. over $282 million the fund lost on Enron Corporation shares. The three-member board, led by Gov. Jeb Bush, told the fund's lawyers to begin negotiations with Alliance to recover the losses and to file suit if Alliance refused to settle.

docs.lead_paragraph: As he faces what is quickly emerging as one of the biggest corporate and accounting scandals of a generation, Harvey L. Pitt is talking tough. Two days ago, Mr. Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, paid a visit to the senior executives in charge of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, the accounting industry's private-sector oversight body.
docs.abstract: SEC chairman Harvey L Pitt, who up until Enron Corp's collapse criticized commission under his predecessor for being too adversarial toward accounting industry, is now taking tough line with industry himself; has criticized Financial Accounting Standards Board, industry's private-sector oversight body, of moving too slowly in adopting new standards, particularly involving bookkeeping treatment of 'special purpose entities,' murky partnerships at center of Enron's unraveling; critics now question whether his early efforts at work cooperatively with firms undercut his latest comments that industry must change its ways; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A New York investor has completed the purchase of Enron Center South, a 40-story office tower that the Enron Corporation was building when it filed for bankruptcy protection. The sale price was $102 million. The investor, Intell Management and Investment, led by Gary Barnett, agreed to acquire the building in an auction supervised by a bankruptcy court in October. The building, with 1.2 million square feet, is across the street from Enron headquarters here. It was designed by Cesar Pelli and cost $300 million to build.
docs.abstract: New York-based Intell Management and Investment, led by Gary Barnett, completes purchase of Enron Center South, 40-story office tower in Houston that Enron Corp was building when it filed for bankruptcy protection; sale price is $102 million (S)

Cisco is an industry leader with $21 billion in cash based on real earnings, no debt and a stock that has returned more than 600 percent, despite the market downturn, since John Chambers became chief executive in 1995. Enron is bankrupt.

docs.lead_paragraph: There are plenty of lessons to be gleaned from the rise and fall of Enron, and business students will be reading about them for years. But students at Oregon State University are not waiting for a textbook. They are now enrolling in a class titled ''The Enron Implosion.'' The seven-week course, which begins on April 8, is so popular that the university has moved it to a 700-seat auditorium.
docs.abstract: So many students have signed up for course on 'The Enron Implosion' at Oregon State University on that it has been moved to 700-seat auditorium (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite intense questioning by a defense lawyer, the former head of Enron's Energy Services retail unit insisted Wednesday that Jeffrey K. Skilling should have known he was committing a crime by lying about a questionable accounting move. The former Enron executive, David W. Delainey, calmly weathered repeated questioning by Daniel Petrocelli, lead lawyer for Mr. Skilling, a former Enron chief executive.
docs.abstract: David W Delainey, former head of Enron's Energy Services retail unit, testifies, despite intense questioning by defense lawyer Daniel Petrocelli, that Jeffrey K Skilling knew he was committing crime by lying about questionable accounting practices; Delainey is highest-ranking former executive to testify so far in trial of Skilling and Enron's founder Kenneth L Lay who were both charged with conspiring to defraud company by lying to investors; defense laywers claim neither were involved in any fraud; says collapse was caused by market panic; photo (M)
